searchDocs.title: new​
searchDocs.content: </> InstanceConstructors.new(...: string | Instance ) → any Returns a new Instance of the given class, wrapping it in a proxy that allows it to be safely used in the sandbox.

searchDocs.title: fromExisting​
searchDocs.content: </> InstanceConstructors.fromExisting(...: Instance ) → () Returns an Instance which is a copy of an existing Instance.

searchDocs.title: Init​
searchDocs.content: </> Sandboxer:Init() → () Initailizes the sandbox environment for the calling script. The following globals are removed: _G / shared SharedTable debug library getfenv setfenv loadstring newproxy xpcall (note: use pcall instead) All other globals are set to sandboxed versions of the originals.

searchDocs.title: Sandbox​
searchDocs.content: </> Sandboxer:Sandbox(fnOrLevel: -Thefunctiontosandboxortheleveltosandboxat.) → () Sandboxes the given function or the calling script at the specified level.

searchDocs.title: Errors
searchDocs.content: Type	DescriptionIf `fnOrLevel` is a number, it must be at least 1.

searchDocs.title: DisallowedClasses​
searchDocs.content: This item is read only and cannot be modified. Read Only </> InstanceList.DisallowedClasses: {string} A list of classes that are not allowed to be created byInstance.new nor Instance.fromExisting. Items can be added to the list, but it cannot be overwritten. Changes to this list will be reflected in the sandbox, even if they are made after the sandbox has been initialized. However, if an Instance of a disallowed class is already created, it will continue to function as normal.

searchDocs.title: ExplicitDisallow​
searchDocs.content: This item is read only and cannot be modified. Read Only </> InstanceList.ExplicitDisallow: {[Instance ]: boolean} A list of Instances that are explicitly disallowed in the sandbox. This is a mapping of Instances to boolean values, which indicate whether the Instance's descendants are allowed or not. Items can be added to the list, but it cannot be overwritten. Changes to this list will be reflected in the sandbox, even if they are made after the sandbox has been initialized. However, if a blocked Instance is already wrapped, it will continue to function as normal.

searchDocs.title: Allow​
searchDocs.content: This item is read only and cannot be modified. Read Only </> InstanceList.Allow: {[Instance ]: boolean} A list of Instances that are allowed in the sandbox. This is a mapping of Instances to boolean values, which indicate whether the Instance's descendants are allowed or not. If any Instance is present in this list, but it is disallowed in ExplicitDisallow, it will be disallowed in the sandbox. Items can be added to the list, but it cannot be overwritten. Changes to this list will be reflected in the sandbox, even if they are made after the sandbox has been initialized. However, if a blocked Instance is already wrapped, it will continue to function as normal.

searchDocs.title: instanceAllowed​
searchDocs.content: </> InstanceList.instanceAllowed( inst: Instance -- The Instance to check. ) → boolean Checks if an Instance is allowed in the sandbox based on Allow and ExplicitDisallow.

searchDocs.title: AnyFn​
searchDocs.content: </> type AnyFn = (...any) → (...any) Function type that all functions can be reduced to.

searchDocs.title: unwrap​
searchDocs.content: </> InstanceSandboxer.unwrap( a: any-- The wrapped Instance or RBXScriptSignal to unwrap. ) → (Instance | RBXScriptSignal )? Unwraps a wrapped Instance or RBXScriptSignal. If the Instance or RBXScriptSignal is not wrapped, it will return nil.

searchDocs.title: isWrapped​
searchDocs.content: </> InstanceSandboxer.isWrapped(a: any) → boolean Checks if a is a wrapped Instance.

searchDocs.title: isWrappedSignal​
searchDocs.content: </> InstanceSandboxer.isWrappedSignal(a: any) → boolean Checks if a is a wrapped RBXScriptSignal.

searchDocs.title: wrapFn​
searchDocs.content: </> InstanceSandboxer.wrapFn( fn: AnyFn-- The function to wrap. ) → AnyFn-- The wrapped function. Wraps a function in a proxy that allows it to be safely used in the sandbox. The wrapped function will return wrapped arguments when called.

searchDocs.title: wrapInstance​
searchDocs.content: </> InstanceSandboxer.wrapInstance( instance: Instance -- The Instance to wrap. ) → any-- The wrapped Instance. Wraps an Instance in a proxy that allows it to be safely used in the sandbox. The proxy will have the same properties, methods, and events as the Instance, but will return wrapped arguments when accessed.

searchDocs.title: deepWrap​
searchDocs.content: </> InstanceSandboxer.deepWrap( v: any,-- The value to deeply wrap. instance: Instance? ,-- The Instance if wrapping one of its properties, methods, or events. key: string?,-- The key of the property, method, or event being wrapped, if applicable. pvisited: {[any]: any}? ) → any Deeply wraps v if it is a table, wrapping Instances and RBXScriptSignals as needed. If v is an Instance or RBXScriptSignal, it will be wrapped and returned.

searchDocs.title: deepUnwrap​
searchDocs.content: </> InstanceSandboxer.deepUnwrap( v: any,-- The value to deeply unwrap. pvisited: {[any]: any}? ) → any Deeply unwraps v if it is a table, unwrapping Instances and RBXScriptSignals as needed. If v is a wrapped Instance or RBXScriptSignal, it will be unwrapped and returned.

searchDocs.title: wrapEvent​
searchDocs.content: </> InstanceSandboxer.wrapEvent( signal: RBXScriptSignal ,-- The RBXScriptSignal to wrap. name: string-- The name of the signal, used for debugging purposes and printing out to console. ) → any-- The wrapped RBXScriptSignal. Wraps an RBXScriptSignal in a proxy that allows it to be safely used in the sandbox. The proxy will have the same methods as an RBXScriptSignal, but will return wrapped arguments when the signal is fired.

searchDocs.title: wrapArgs​
searchDocs.content: </> InstanceSandboxer.wrapArgs(...: any) → ...any Deeply wraps all arguments passed to the function, making them ready to be returned to the sandboxed environment.

searchDocs.title: unwrapArgs​
searchDocs.content: </> InstanceSandboxer.unwrapArgs(...: any) → ...any Deeply unwraps all arguments passed to the function (usually from inside the sandbox), making them ready to be used in a method call on an Instance.
